    • Field Detail

      • helpListener

        public static java.awt.event.ActionListener helpListener
        This is a listener that is notified when a help component is clicked. When a help component is created, an Object is associated with it known as "helpData".

        The default helpListener looks at the helpData object and, if it a URL (or a String that can be converted to a URL), then BrowserLauncher.openURL() is called.

        If you implement your own helpListner, it should probably include:
        JComponent src = (JComponent)e.getSource();
        Object helpData = src.getClientProperty("helpData");

        (Do not assume the source is a button: on Windows the source may be a JLink, which is an extension of a JLabel.)

    • Constructor Detail

      • HelpComponent

        public HelpComponent()

    • Method Detail

      • createHelpComponent

        public static javax.swing.JComponent createHelpComponent(java.lang.Object helpData,
                                                         java.lang.String helpText)
        This returns a JComponent that can be used to trigger help.

        On Mac, this will return a JButton that has the correct icon (see Apple Technical Note 2196). This button will have the tooltip helpText, if that string is non-null.

        On other platforms, this will return a JLink with the text helpText. If helpText is null, then the text "Learn More" is used. This is based on Vista's advice: "Don't use general or vague Help topic links or generic Help buttons. Users often ignore generic Help." The Vista guidelines go on to explicitly discourage using "Learn More" because it comes across as too general/common, so it is encouraged that you provide an accurate string to encourage your users to follow the link. (Also Microsoft points out you should: "Design your UI so that users don't need Help," and "Understand that you don't have to provide help for every feature in the UI.")

        Parameters:
        helpData - an object (preferably a URL) indicating what this button should do.

        The default helpListener expects this to be a URL or a String representing a URL, but you can pass any object here and implement your own helpListener if needed.

        helpText - text associated with this help. On Mac this is the tooltip of the button, and on other platforms this text is the link.
        Returns:
        a JComponent used to retrieve help.
